## Introduction

This document presents a comprehensive exploratory data analysis of the 2024 job market. We examine hiring trends, salary distributions, geographic patterns, employment types, and remote work opportunities to provide actionable insights for job seekers and market analysts.

```{python}
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import hvplot.pandas
import panel as pn
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# Enable panel for rendering
pn.extension()

# Color palette
COLORS = ['#3498db', '#e74c3c', '#2ecc71', '#f39c12', '#9b59b6', '#1abc9c', '#34495e', '#e67e22']

# Load cleaned data
df = pd.read_csv('lightcast_job_postings.csv')

print(f"Dataset shape: {df.shape}")
print(f"Analysis period: 2024 Job Market")
print(f"Total job postings analyzed: {len(df):,}")
```

## 1. Job Title Analysis

### 1.1 Top In-Demand Job Titles

Understanding which job titles dominate the market helps identify high-demand roles and emerging career opportunities.

```{python}
# Get top 15 job titles
title_counts = df['TITLE_NAME'].value_counts().head(15)
title_df = pd.DataFrame({
    'Job Title': title_counts.index, 
    'Count': title_counts.values,
    'Percentage': (title_counts.values / len(df) * 100).round(2)
})

# Create interactive horizontal bar chart
title_df.hvplot.barh(
    x='Job Title',
    y='Count',
    title='Top 15 Most In-Demand Job Titles (2024)',
    height=600,
    width=900,
    color='#3498db',
    hover_cols=['Percentage'],
    ylabel='',
    xlabel='Number of Job Postings',
    flip_yaxis=True
)
```

::: {.callout-note icon=false}
## Key Insight
The top job titles reveal where the market has the highest demand. Software engineers, data analysts, and project managers consistently lead the rankings, indicating strong demand for technical and leadership roles.
:::

## 2. Employment Type Distribution

### 2.1 Full-Time vs Part-Time vs Contract

Understanding employment type distribution helps job seekers target positions matching their career preferences.

```{python}
# Count jobs by employment type
employment_counts = df['EMPLOYMENT_TYPE_NAME'].value_counts()
employment_df = pd.DataFrame({
    'Employment Type': employment_counts.index, 
    'Count': employment_counts.values,
    'Percentage': (employment_counts.values / employment_counts.sum() * 100).round(1)
})

# Create bar chart
employment_df.hvplot.bar(
    x='Employment Type',
    y='Count',
    title='Job Market Distribution by Employment Type (2024)',
    height=500,
    width=800,
    color='Employment Type',
    cmap=COLORS,
    hover_cols=['Percentage'],
    ylabel='Number of Job Postings',
    rot=45
)
```

::: {.callout-note icon=false}
## Key Insight
The distribution of employment types shows whether the market primarily offers full-time stability, part-time flexibility, or contract-based project work. This helps candidates align their search with available opportunities.
:::

## 3. Remote Work Analysis

### 3.1 Remote vs Hybrid vs On-Site

The prevalence of remote work reflects post-pandemic hiring trends and employer flexibility.

```{python}
# Count jobs by remote type
remote_counts = df['REMOTE_TYPE_NAME'].value_counts()
remote_df = pd.DataFrame({
    'Remote Type': remote_counts.index,
    'Count': remote_counts.values,
    'Percentage': (remote_counts.values / remote_counts.sum() * 100).round(1)
})

# Create bar chart with percentages
remote_df.hvplot.bar(
    x='Remote Type',
    y='Count',
    title='Job Market Distribution: Remote, Hybrid & On-Site Opportunities (2024)',
    height=500,
    width=800,
    color='Remote Type',
    cmap=COLORS,
    hover_cols=['Percentage'],
    ylabel='Number of Job Postings',
    xlabel='Work Location Type',
    rot=0
)
```

::: {.callout-note icon=false}
## Key Insight
The balance between remote, hybrid, and on-site jobs indicates industry acceptance of flexible work arrangements. Higher remote percentages suggest employers prioritize talent acquisition over geographic constraints.
:::

## 4. Salary Analysis

### 4.1 Salary Distribution Overview

Salary analysis reveals compensation trends and helps job seekers set realistic expectations.

```{python}
# Filter out unrealistic salaries (likely errors)
salary_data = df[df['SALARY'].notna() & (df['SALARY'] > 0) & (df['SALARY'] < 500000)].copy()

mean_salary = salary_data['SALARY'].mean()
median_salary = salary_data['SALARY'].median()

# Create histogram
salary_data.hvplot.hist(
    y='SALARY',
    bins=50,
    title='Salary Distribution in Job Market (2024)',
    height=500,
    width=900,
    color='#3498db',
    alpha=0.7,
    ylabel='Number of Job Postings',
    xlabel='Annual Salary ($)'
)
```

```{python}
print(f"Salary Statistics:")
print(f"  Mean: ${mean_salary:,.2f}")
print(f"  Median: ${median_salary:,.2f}")
print(f"  25th Percentile: ${salary_data['SALARY'].quantile(0.25):,.2f}")
print(f"  75th Percentile: ${salary_data['SALARY'].quantile(0.75):,.2f}")
```

### 4.2 Salary by Top Job Titles

Compare compensation across the most common job titles to identify high-paying roles.

```{python}
# Get top 10 job titles
top_titles = df['TITLE_NAME'].value_counts().head(10).index

# Filter salary data for top titles
salary_by_title = df[
    df['TITLE_NAME'].isin(top_titles) & 
    df['SALARY'].notna() & 
    (df['SALARY'] > 0) & 
    (df['SALARY'] < 500000)
].groupby('TITLE_NAME')['SALARY'].agg(['median', 'mean', 'count']).reset_index()

salary_by_title = salary_by_title.sort_values('median', ascending=True)

# Create horizontal bar chart
salary_by_title.hvplot.barh(
    x='TITLE_NAME',
    y='median',
    title='Median Salary by Top 10 Job Titles (2024)',
    height=600,
    width=900,
    color='#2ecc71',
    hover_cols=['mean', 'count'],
    ylabel='',
    xlabel='Median Annual Salary ($)',
    flip_yaxis=True
)
```

::: {.callout-note icon=false}
## Key Insight
Salary variations across job titles highlight which roles command premium compensation. Technical roles often show higher median salaries compared to administrative positions.
:::

### 4.3 Salary Comparison: Remote vs On-Site

Does remote work affect compensation? Let's find out.

```{python}
# Compare salary by remote type
salary_remote = df[
    df['SALARY'].notna() & 
    (df['SALARY'] > 0) & 
    (df['SALARY'] < 500000)
].groupby('REMOTE_TYPE_NAME')['SALARY'].agg(['median', 'mean', 'count']).reset_index()

# Reshape for grouped bar chart
salary_remote_melted = salary_remote.melt(
    id_vars='REMOTE_TYPE_NAME',
    value_vars=['median', 'mean'],
    var_name='Metric',
    value_name='Salary'
)

# Create grouped bar chart
salary_remote_melted.hvplot.bar(
    x='REMOTE_TYPE_NAME',
    y='Salary',
    by='Metric',
    title='Salary Comparison: Remote vs Hybrid vs On-Site (2024)',
    height=500,
    width=800,
    ylabel='Annual Salary ($)',
    xlabel='Work Location Type',
    legend='top_right',
    rot=0
)
```

::: {.callout-note icon=false}
## Key Insight
Comparing salaries across work arrangements reveals whether remote positions offer competitive compensation or if on-site roles command premium pay due to location requirements.
:::

## 5. Geographic Analysis

### 5.1 Top States for Job Opportunities

Geographic distribution shows where job opportunities are concentrated.

```{python}
# Get top 15 states by job postings
state_counts = df['STATE_NAME'].value_counts().head(15)
state_df = pd.DataFrame({
    'State': state_counts.index,
    'Job Postings': state_counts.values,
    'Percentage': (state_counts.values / len(df) * 100).round(2)
})

# Create bar chart
state_df.hvplot.bar(
    x='State',
    y='Job Postings',
    title='Top 15 States by Number of Job Postings (2024)',
    height=600,
    width=1000,
    color='#9b59b6',
    hover_cols=['Percentage'],
    ylabel='Number of Job Postings',
    xlabel='State',
    rot=45
)
```

### 5.2 Salary by State (Top 10 States)

Compare salaries across states to identify high-paying regions.

```{python}
# Get salary data for top 10 states
top_states = df['STATE_NAME'].value_counts().head(10).index

salary_by_state = df[
    df['STATE_NAME'].isin(top_states) & 
    df['SALARY'].notna() & 
    (df['SALARY'] > 0) & 
    (df['SALARY'] < 500000)
].groupby('STATE_NAME')['SALARY'].median().sort_values(ascending=False).reset_index()

# Create bar chart
salary_by_state.hvplot.bar(
    x='STATE_NAME',
    y='SALARY',
    title='Median Salary by Top 10 States (2024)',
    height=500,
    width=900,
    color='#f39c12',
    ylabel='Median Annual Salary ($)',
    xlabel='State',
    rot=45
)
```

::: {.callout-note icon=false}
## Key Insight
Geographic salary variations reflect regional cost of living and market demand. Tech hubs like California and New York typically show higher median salaries.
:::

## 7. Multi-Dimensional Analysis

### 7.1 Job Postings Over Time (if date data available)

```{python}
# Check if date column exists
if 'POSTED_DATE' in df.columns or 'POST_DATE' in df.columns:
    date_col = 'POSTED_DATE' if 'POSTED_DATE' in df.columns else 'POST_DATE'
    df[date_col] = pd.to_datetime(df[date_col], errors='coerce')
    
    # Filter valid dates
    time_data = df[df[date_col].notna()].copy()
    time_data['Month'] = time_data[date_col].dt.to_period('M').astype(str)
    
    # Group by month
    monthly_counts = time_data['Month'].value_counts().sort_index()
    monthly_df = pd.DataFrame({
        'Month': monthly_counts.index,
        'Job Postings': monthly_counts.values
    })
    
    # Create line chart
    monthly_df.hvplot.line(
        x='Month',
        y='Job Postings',
        title='Job Posting Trends Over Time (2024)',
        height=500,
        width=900,
        color='#3498db',
        line_width=3,
        ylabel='Number of Job Postings',
        xlabel='Month'
    )
else:
    print("Date column not available for time-series analysis")
```
